item.title: 40 Years and 10,000 Broadcasts In, They’re Still Live on Air
item.description: Rick Ardon and Susannah Carr have been delivering the news together in Western Australia since 1985 — a Guinness World Record.
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson and Matthew Abbott

item.title: Oil Shipments in Persian Gulf Already Disrupted by Iran Attack
item.description: Tankers have begun to steer clear of the region and the Strait of Hormuz, threatening to push up energy prices.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott and Peter Eavis
item.category: US and Israeli Attack on Iran (2026)
item.media:credit: Giuseppe Cacace/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Cargo ships and oil tankers in the Strait of Hormuz earlier this week.

item.title: Berkshire Hathaway Posts a Drop in Earnings in Buffett’s Last Year
item.description: In his first report as C.E.O., Gregory Abel, stuck to a straight commentary rather than Warren Buffett’s folksy tone. The lower earnings were largely driven by declines in the insurance business.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:credit: Brendan Mcdermid/Reuters
item.media:description: Gregory E. Abel, right, the new chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, with a Berkshire shareholder at the conglomerate’s annual meeting last year.

item.title: Banks Are Becoming Bulwarks for Vulnerable Seniors
item.description: Older Americans are losing billions of dollars annually to financial exploitation. Banks and investment firms are training employees to spot red flags and stop the transactions.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span
item.media:credit: Federica Bordoni

item.title: Lloyd Blankfein on Trump, Epstein and Life After Goldman Sachs
item.description: In a wide-ranging interview with Andrew Ross Sorkin, Goldman’s former C.E.O. discussed his life and new memoir.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin
item.media:credit: Oliver Farshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lloyd Blankfein, a former C.E.O. of Goldman Sachs, has published a memoir.

item.title: Netflix Lost Warner. Maybe That’s a Good Thing.
item.description: It is entirely possible, analysts say, that Netflix will be better off by bailing from its $83 billion deal with Warner Bros. Discovery.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.media:credit: Aleksey Kondratyev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Netflix’s offices on Sunset Boulevard in Los Angeles. “The truth is, Netflix is still producing more hits than everyone else combined,” one analyst said.

item.title: Warner Bros. Employees Glum About Prospect of Paramount Ownership
item.description: Employees at the company had started to warm to the idea of Netflix as its corporate owner. Now they face the prospect of major cuts under Paramount.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes and John Koblin
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Warner Bros. Studio in Burbank, California.

item.title: QAnon Faithful See Validation in the Epstein Files
item.description: The nearly decade-old conspiracy theory does not align neatly with the facts emerging from the documents. That does not seem to matter.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu and Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: QAnon followers see validation of their theories in some elements of the Epstein files. But other parts of their canon, including the existence of a deep-state pedophilia conspiracy, are not backed up by the files.

item.title: 4 Ways to Enjoy Your Savings in Retirement Without Going Broke
item.description: Once paychecks stop, it can be frightening to shift out of the savings habit. But there are strategies to enjoy your nest egg and make it last.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Rabasca Roepe
item.media:credit: Amber Baesler for The New York Times
item.media:description: LeeAnn and Randy Smith had spent decades saving and investing, but were afraid they’d run out of money and have to rely on their children.

item.title: New Geothermal Technology Aims to Produce Clean Energy in Germany
item.description: Developers are using a new geothermal technology in Germany to produce clean energy.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Roderick Aichinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Detail of the teeth of a drill bit that will be used in the next phase of drilling.

item.title: In a Memoir Draft, Changpeng Zhao of Binance Details the Talks Leading to His Prison Time
item.description: In a draft of his memoir, Changpeng Zhao, the founder of Binance, laid out the secret negotiations that led to his imprisonment and a run-in with ICE.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Mattathias Schwartz
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
item.media:description: Binance’s founder, Changpeng Zhao, outside federal court in Seattle in 2024 at his sentencing for violating an anti-money-laundering law.

item.title: Justice Dept. Tries to Slow Down Legal Battle Over Tariff Refunds
item.description: Earlier, President Trump suggested on social media that he could try to persuade the Supreme Court to reconsider its rejection of his tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump rebuked the Supreme Court again on Friday.

item.title: Instagram to Alert Parents to Teens’ Self-Harm Searches
item.description: Parents will receive notifications if a child has used the platform repeatedly to search for terms related to suicide or self-harm, but users must opt in to get them.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:credit: Dado Ruvic/Reuters
item.media:description: Meta, which owns Instagram, is promoting the parental alerts about searches for harmful content as it is on trial in two states over claims that its platforms are addictive and have harmed young users.

item.title: Iris Cantor, Philanthropist and Art Collector, Dies at 95
item.description: She and her husband, the financier B. Gerald Cantor, amassed one of the largest private collections of Rodin artworks, donating much of it to museums around the world.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:credit: Gabe Palacio/ImageDirect, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Iris Cantor in 2001. A former model and stockbroker, she joined the bond brokerage firm Cantor Fitzgerald in 1967 and later married the founder, B. Gerald Cantor.

item.title: How David Zaslav Pulled Off the Sale of Warner Bros. Discovery to Paramount
item.description: Not long ago, Mr. Zaslav was widely criticized for his management of Warner Bros. Discovery. He overcame the doubters, cementing a blockbuster sale to Paramount.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images
item.media:description: The deal will make David Zaslav, the chief executive of Warner Bros. Discovery, an even richer man.

item.title: Overlooked No More: Bobby Garnett, ‘Godfather’ of Vintage Dealers
item.description: His store, Bobby From Boston, transformed the way vintage men’s wear is sold, serving as a model for a generation of retailers.
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz
item.media:credit: Janet Knott/The Boston Globe via Getty Images

item.title: Pentagon-Anthropic Standoff Is a Decisive Moment for How A.I. Will Be Used in War
item.description: The Pentagon’s contract dispute with Anthropic is part of a wider clash about the use of artificial intelligence for national security and who decides on any safeguards.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Julian E. Barnes and Sheera Frenkel
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Pentagon has said that a private contractor cannot decide how its tools will be lawfully used for national security.

item.title: Trump Media Explores Spinning Off Truth Social
item.description: The move would split off the money-losing social media platform as the company pursues a merger with a fusion power company.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley and Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: The announcement named Texas Ventures Acquisition III, a Cayman Islands-based SPAC, as the company with which Truth Social would be merged.

item.title: OpenAI Raises $110 Billion Led by Amazon, Nvidia and SoftBank, Extending A.I. Boom
item.description: Amazon, Nvidia and SoftBank led the investment, valuing the parent of ChatGPT at $730 billion.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz and Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Andres Kudacki for The New York Times
item.media:description: OpenAI said it now has over 900 million weekly active users and more than 50 million paying subscribers.

item.title: The I.R.S. Shut Its Direct File, but Here Are Other Free Filing Options
item.description: The agency still offers a Free File program that works with commercial tax software firms. Some companies also offer free tools for certain filers.
item.dc:creator: Ann Carrns

item.title: E.U. Pushes Ahead With South American Trade Deal Despite Legal Challenge
item.description: The provisional application of the agreement with Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay is intended to diversify Europe’s trading relationships.
item.dc:creator: Koba Ryckewaert and Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Ander Gillenea/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The trade deal has been contentious in parts of Europe, with farmers staging protests, like this one in Bilbao, Spain, in recent months.

item.title: Paramount Is Set to Win Warner Bros. Now Comes the Hard Part.
item.description: The media company controlled by the Ellisons out-dueled Netflix for control of Warner Bros. Discovery. The next step is making the combined media empires work.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Grady McGregor and Ian Mount
item.media:credit: Jae C. Hong/Associated Press
item.media:description: Paramount will become a much bigger force in Hollywood now that it appears likely to take over Warner Bros. Discovery.

item.title: How India Became One of the World’s Biggest Economies
item.description: India has grown rapidly despite its slow industrialization, and its economy is now nearly as big as Japan’s.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Aaron Krolik
item.media:credit: Ludovic Marin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: India’s small businesses employ the most workers, but a growing share of economic gains is coming from its largest companies.

item.title: For CNN, a Takeover by Paramount Means a Suddenly Uncertain Future
item.description: Paramount’s apparent victory over Netflix in securing Warner Bros. Discovery has led to concerns within the CNN newsroom about editorial independence.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum and John Koblin
item.media:credit: Kevin Mazur/Getty Images
item.media:description: Mark Thompson, CNN’s chief executive, urged staff members not to “jump to conclusions” about Paramount’s offer for the network’s parent, Warner Bros. Discovery.

item.title: What Larry and David Ellison Would Own After Warner Bros. Takeover
item.description: If Paramount can close its deal to buy Warner Bros. Discovery, Larry and David Ellison will influence nearly every corner of news, entertainment and tech.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin and Brooks Barnes
item.media:credit: Clive Brunskill/Getty Images
item.media:description: Larry and David Ellison are poised to own a portfolio of companies that would put them in the orbit of superpowers like Disney.

item.title: A World Where All Is Free? That’s Elon Musk’s Theory of ‘Sustainable Abundance.’
item.description: The Tesla and SpaceX chief has told his followers that they will live in a world where robots will take care of every need and people do not have to work, in what has become his latest slogan.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac
item.media:credit: Brandon Celi

item.title: The Web of Companies Owned by Elon Musk
item.description: In mapping out Elon Musk’s wealth, our investigation found that Mr. Musk is behind more than 90 companies in Texas. Kirsten Grind, a New York Times Investigations reporter, explains what her team found.
item.dc:creator: Kirsten Grind, Melanie Bencosme, James Surdam and Sean Havey

item.title: The Rise and Fall of a 3-D Printing Empire
item.description: Desktop Metal, a billion-dollar start-up, promised to revolutionize manufacturing. It went bankrupt, and now has much humbler ambitions as the 3-D printing industry takes a sober turn.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman
item.media:credit: Tony Luong for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jonah Myerberg, co-founder and chief technology officer at Desktop Metal, with one of the company’s industrial 3-D metal printers. The Burlington, Mass., firm declared bankruptcy last year.

item.title: Elon Musk’s Secret Web of Companies in Texas
item.description: The megabillionaire was tied to about 90 companies in the state, which he uses for everything from paying nannies to buying land to supporting Donald Trump’s re-election, according to a Times examination.
item.dc:creator: Kirsten Grind, Susanne Craig, Alex Klavens and Leo Dominguez
item.media:credit: Jordan Vonderhaar for The New York Times

item.title: Honolulu on a Budget
item.description: Hawaii is expensive, but basing yourself in the capital, where local culture and nature are within easy reach, can save you money on lodgings and food, leaving funds for a few splurges.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac and Michelle Mishina Kunz
item.media:credit: Michelle Mishina Kunz for The New York Times

item.title: South Korea Clears Way for Google Maps to Fully Operate
item.description: South Korea approved Google’s request to export detailed map data, reversing a longstanding restriction that made the tool largely nonfunctional.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Kim Hong-Ji/Reuters
item.media:description: Unlike in most countries, Google Maps has not provided real-time driving or walking directions in South Korea.

item.title: With a New Nigeria Refinery, Africa’s Richest Man Wants ‘to Rescue the Country’
item.description: Aliko Dangote, Africa’s richest man, has an ambitious vision for the continent’s most populous nation, but hurdles stand in his way.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey
item.media:credit: Victor Adewale for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aliko Dangote at home in Lagos, Nigeria, last month.

item.title: India Built the World’s Back Office. A.I. Is Starting to Shrink It.
item.description: Artificial intelligence promises to automate the white-collar work that made India a tech powerhouse. The country is racing to adapt before it’s too late.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers, Paul Mozur and Saumya Khandelwal
item.media:description: Hunar.AI is offering companies bespoke A.I. voice agents that steer job applicants through virtually every step of the hiring process.

item.title: Germany’s Oil and Gas Output Is Dwindling as Prices Rise
item.description: Natural gas production in Germany has fallen about 80 percent in the past two decades even as the country seeks to replace flows from Russia.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed and Maximilian Mann
item.media:description: The Gas Nord production facility of Harbour Energy Germany in Langwedel-Holtebüttel.

item.title: 32.6 Million Watched Trump’s State of the Union Address, Nielsen Says
item.description: The audience was roughly on par with former President Biden’s final State of the Union address in 2024.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Congressional staff members watching President Trump’s State of the Union address at the Capitol on Tuesday.

item.title: Block Cuts 40% of Its Work Force Because of Its Embrace of A.I.
item.description: About 4,000 workers will lose their jobs as the payments company does more work with new artificial intelligence tools, its top executive said.
item.dc:creator: Natallie Rocha
item.media:credit: Koshiro K/Alamy
item.media:description: Jack Dorsey, Block’s top executive, attributed job cuts to his company’s embrace of A.I.

item.title: Netflix Backs Out of Bid for Warner Bros., Paving Way for Paramount Takeover
item.description: The move was a stunning development in the long-running corporate battle for the storied media giant.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch, Michael M. Grynbaum and Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paramount Pictures in Hollywood.

item.title: Oliver Grant, a Business Architect of the Wu-Tang Clan, Dies
item.description: He was behind the scenes with Wu-Tang Clan, the New York rap group, since its founding and helped expand its reach with a fashion line.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Efren Landaos/SOPA Images/LightRocket, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Oliver Grant at the premiere of the “Wu-Tang: An American Saga” television series in New York City in 2019.

item.title: FedEx Says It Could Return Tariff Refunds to Customers
item.description: The company sued the administration days after the Supreme Court ruled against the president’s duties.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: FedEx has pledged to return money to shippers and customers if a federal court orders the Trump administration to refund tariffs it charged the company.

item.title: U.S. Mortgage Rates Fall Below 6% for First Time in Years
item.description: The evidence is patchy on whether lower rates have meaningfully spurred more activity, as the Trump administration floats measures it says will make housing more affordable.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Schmidt
item.category: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp (Freddie Mac)
item.media:credit: Carlos Bernate for The New York Times

item.title: Why Estrogen Patches For Menopause Are So Hard to Find
item.description: Changing attitudes around menopause treatment have driven up demand for hormone therapy.
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.media:credit: Associated Press

item.title: They Helped Women Fight Online Abuse. They Were Barred From the U.S.
item.description: The founders of HateAid, a German human-rights group that helps victims of online attacks, were accused by the Trump administration of being part of a “global censorship-industrial complex.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Patrick Junker
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Patrick Junker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna-Lena von Hodenberg, left, and Josephine Ballon, right, of the organization HateAid. The group provides legal support for victims of digital violence and engages in policy advocacy aimed at strengthening accountability for major online platforms.

item.title: How a Close Associate of Epstein’s Found Career Redemption in Japan
item.description: Top Japanese officials are backing a tech and entrepreneurship initiative led in part by Joichi Ito, whose involvement with Jeffrey Epstein may endanger efforts to get the project off the ground.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Hisako Ueno

item.title: He Hopes to Turn the Island of Nevis Into a Libertarian Paradise, With Crypto
item.description: A Bitcoin baron wants to build a libertarian paradise on the island of Nevis. Democracy is getting in the way.
item.dc:creator: Atossa Araxia Abrahamian
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olivier Janssens, propelled by his cryptocurrency fortune, wants to build an enclave where residents would have special rights on Nevis.

item.title: Why Nvidia’s Big Profits Aren’t Lifting Markets
item.description: The chip giant at the center of the artificial intelligence boom again beat expectations. But it didn’t overcome investor jitters.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly and Brian O’Keefe
item.media:credit: Mikayla Whitmore for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jensen Huang’s Nvidia just blew away Wall Street estimates. But to investors’ chagrin, that performance has failed to move the market.

item.title: Revel, a Maker of Software for Running Hardware, Raises $150 Million
item.description: The start-up, founded by a former top SpaceX engineer, promises to help companies reduce their testing times and optimize systems.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced

item.title: World Economic Forum Chief Resigns Over Epstein Ties
item.description: Borge Brende, a former foreign minister of Norway, had maintained contact with the convicted sex offender.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Fabrice Coffrini/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Borge Brende led the World Economic Forum, which runs an annual summit in Davos, Switzerland, for more than eight years.

item.title: Z? Zo? Mam? Mayor Zohran Mamdani is a Man of Many Nicknames.
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani has been given a bevy of nicknames by New York City’s tabloid newspapers and political class. Which will stick?
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum and Eliza Shapiro
item.media:credit: Mark Harris

item.title: New A.C.A. Plans Could Increase Family Deductibles to $31,000
item.description: The Trump administration is proposing Obamacare plans that it says will lower health insurance premiums. But critics warn they would make care unaffordable.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Mehmet Oz, who oversees Medicare and Medicaid, promoted new proposals that he said would lower costs. Critics fear the options will increase medical bills and drive people out of insurance plans.
